Award.AwardTitle: INTEROP: A Community-Driven Scientific Observations Network to Achieve Interoperability of Environmental and Ecological Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will build a "Scientific Observations Network"--as a multi-disciplinary, community-driven effort to define and develop a unified model for observational data, to enhance data sharing, merging and reuse in the earth and life sciences. This effort will coordinate work of a community of experts drawn from numerous disciplines, including ecology, hydrology, oceanography, geo-sciences, the geospatial community, and life sciences, working closely with computer scientists and information managers, to develop necessary specifications and technologies to facilitate intelligent interpretation and seamless integration of observational data. Advances in environmental science and ecology increasingly depend on information from multiple disciplines to address broad, complex questions about the natural world. Researchers are extremely challenged, however, in effectively locating, interpreting, and integrating data that might be relevant for these investigations. This is due to extreme variability in the structure and contents of the data that scientists collect. This project will support the growing interest in the earth and life sciences in the possibilities of describing data at the level of observation and measurement, rather than the traditional focus at the level of the data set, in order to achieve stronger data discovery and interoperability.

The Scientific Observations Network will work to develop compatible, open-source, standards-based approaches to the semantic modeling of observational data. A key goal will be the development of a core conceptual data model for representing scientific observations. This core observations model will provide a common basis for developing, extending, and applying highly specialized scientific terminologies required for detailed descriptions of data relevant for environmental research. Subgroups of experts will engage in extending the core data model to include a broad range of specific measurements collected by the representative disciplines, and a series of demonstration projects will illustrate the capabilities of these approaches to confederate data for reuse in broader and unanticipated contexts. The scientific Observations Network will help to insure that scientific data, once collected, is put to the greatest possible use by the broadest group of users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Internet is rapidly transforming scientific research by enabling ever more rapid exchange of ideas, data, and algorithms, in ways that were inconceivable just two decades ago. While Google and other Web search engines provide excellent ways to roughly locate items of scientific interest, these services often point one to an overwhelming number of documents, with many being irrelevant. What is needed for the scientific research community is a more precise and rigorous means of searching the Web, allowing for increased clarity and specificity in locating items of scientific interest.

Of particular promise in realizing this goal is the use of expressive, logic-based languages, such as RDF and OWL, that are recommended by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) for enabling clear and precise descriptions of scientific phenomena. A Semantic Web can be created by describing and inter-relating Web resources through domain-specialized vocabularies,or ontologies, constructed using the RDF/OWL languages.

This Scientific Observations Network (SONet) project, explored how Semantic Web technologies can advance scientists' capabilities to more efficiently discover, exchange, and interpret one another's data. SONet was motivated by the realization that a number of environmental, earth, and life science disciplines were building ontologies, and many of these were converging on a generalized model for Observations and Measurements to describe their respective data. Scientific data are often collected about some entities of interest, along with measurements of some characteristics or properties that these entities exhibit. For example, in fruit fly genetics, you might observe a "white-eye" mutation, while in oceanography you might measure a "sea-surface temperature". In both cases there is an involvement of entities-- the fruit fly organism and its eyes-- and a characteristic of those eyes, that is, their color (property) of white. In the oceanographic case, there is the entity of the sea, and its properties-- of a sample of ocean water taken from the surface having a temperature. It is common for scientists to use short-hand in describing such phenomena in their data-- often neglecting to specify, e.g. that a white eye is observed on a fruit fly; or that a temperature is taken from ocean surface waters. Yet these are important semantic features to expose to other researchers, to aid in data discovery, interpretation and re-use.  

A major goal of SONet was to derive consensus and harmonize several leading models for Observations and Measurements, that were undergoing independent development in the life, hydrological, geospatial, ecological, and biodiversity science communities. A harmonized model would assure that both the entity, and its characteristics are specified, along with the units (e.g. kg) of measurement, if relevant, using well-defined "standard" descriptors that are broadly accepted by the scientific community. In addition, by sharing a common model for Observations and Measurements, disparate scientific disciplines  will gain in the power and precision of their "semantic" searches--accelerating resource discovery, improving cross disciplinary data use, and thus enhancing scientific innovation and synthesis.

 A further goal of SONet was to promote the value of Semantic Web approaches in formalizing these relationships, rather than using other modeling languages, e.g. metadata standards such as XMLS, UML, or entity-relationship specifications. The OWL and RDF languages offer a rich set of logical expressivity to enable automated computer-assisted reasoning, that surpass the capabilities of other modeling languages commonly used today.

Through a series of NSF-sponsored meetings over the past five years, over 50 individuals from diverse scientific disciplines participated in developing a common, formal W3C-compliant specification for observations and measurements. Over the course of the project, two postdoctoral associates (both now in research positions) and two graduate students also assisted in developing and testing a confederation model. SONet achieved its goal of reaching convergence and harmonization of these observational models.  In particular, various parties from the geosciences, ecology, hydrology, and genomics have modified their individual models, and jointly mapped correspondences, using RDF/OWL, to create greater interoperability of observational data among the various domains specified above.

A second major accomplishment of the SONet effort was to initiate the creation of a set of domain ontologies that conform to the Observations and Measurements specifications.  While still in the prototype stage, these ontologies are being tested with new applications that automatically bind well-defined ontological concepts to data contained in national-scale environmental repositories, as well as allow researchers to annotate their data with these ontological concepts, such that the details of what they measured are much clearer. 

With the growth of standards for sharing information over the Web, we are entering a new era of how scientists can better communicate with one another by using rigorous, community-based vocabularies for describing their data and analyses. SONet represents a significant step along the road towards building community agreement on how to semantically model the essential contents of many critical data sets, focusing on the specific observations and measurements contained therein.
